repnme.cdata!:
Chad and Cameroon - Petroleum Development
            and Pipeline Project; Cameroon -  Petroleum Capacity
            Enhancement Project; Chad - Petroleum Sector Management
            Capacity-Building Project; and Chad - Petroleum Economy
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Petroleum Development
            and Pipeline Project for Chad and Cameroon are as follows:
            outcome was moderately satisfactory; risk to the development
            outcome was significant; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Petroleum Capacity Enhancement
            Project for Cameroon are as follows:  outcome was
            unsatisfactory; risk to the development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory;
            and Borrower performance was o moderately unsatisfactory.
            Ratings for the Petroleum Sector Management
            Capacity-Building Project for Chad are as follows: outcome
            was unsatisfactory; risks to development outcome were high;
            Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Petroleum
            Economy Management Project for Chad are as follows:  outcome
            was unsatisfactory; risks to development outcome were high;
            Bank performance was unsatisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was highly unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: it is imperative to design projects in light of
            the institutional and administrative capacity realities. In
            countries with weak capacity, it is important to focus on
            addressing the basic problems rather than attempting to
            introduce sophisticated practices. Paradoxically, major
            components of the program in effect assumed the existence of
            the very capacity they aimed to build. The temptation to put
            in place special mechanisms to protect specific resources
            and accomplish results is understandable in a weak capacity
            and governance environment, but institutional enclaves are
            generally not successful beyond the short term and even when
            successful in the short term they tend to undermine the
            already weak local systems and thus long-term development.

repnme.cdata!:
Chad-Cameroon Petroleum Development and
            Pipeline Project : overview

abstracts.cdata!:
This document has been prepared as a
            supplement to the Implementation Completion Report being
            submitted to the World Bank's Board of Directors. It
            provides an overview of the World Bank's support for
            the petroleum sector in Chad and Cameroon which included two
            IBRD loans to Chad and Cameroon for the main Petroleum
            Development and Pipeline Project in Chad and Cameroon and
            three IDA credits for capacity-building projects-one in
            Cameroon and two in Chad. It describes the context in which
            the projects were developed, the issues raised about World
            Bank participation, the development of the lending
            instruments used, the implementation of the projects
            (including monitoring), and the two investigations
            undertaken by the World Bank Inspection Panel. It also
            provides a description of civil society's contribution
            to the unique implementation arrangements and the lessons
            learned from the Project thus far.

repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Petroleum Development and
            Pipeline Project; and Environment Capacity Enhancement
            (CAPECE) Project : Management Response to Request for Inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The Management Response to Request for
            Inspection details the Petroleum Development and Pipeline
            Project background and the creation of the Petroleum
            Environment Capacity Enhancement Project (CAPECE).  The
            Response disputes the claims of the Request, stating that
            the pipeline has very little impact in Cameroon, both
            environmentally and aesthetically.  The Response states that
            infrastructure around the pipeline will improve due to the
            creation of roads and that the land around the pipeline will
            be available for farming and grazing.  It is acknowledged
            that the health services branch of the project has advanced
            the least.  There are currently plans to collect data on the
            needs of the communities and provide appropriate medical
            services where needed.  There are also plans to continue
            developing and strengthening the national capacity to deal
            with oil spills.  The Management's response to other
            claims, including water pollution and loss of fishing areas,
            states that these areas will be monitored, although losses
            and contamination appear to be minimal.  The Annexes address
            individual claims from various communities and provide
            detailed responses to each.  The Management states that it
            believes the Bank has made every effort to follow policy and
            procedure in this project and that the Requestors'
            right and interests have not been adversely affected by the Bank.

repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Petroleum Development and
            Pipeline Project, and Petroleum Environment Capacity
            Enhancement  Project : Management Report and Recommendation
            in Response to the Inspection Panel Report

abstracts.cdata!:
On September 30,2002 the Inspection
            Panel registered a Request for Inspection, (hereafter
            referred to as "the Request"), concerning the
            Petroleum Development and Pipeline Project in Cameroon (the
            "Pipeline Project"), financed by the International
            Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), and the
            Petroleum Environment Capacity Enhancement (CAPECE) Project
            in Cameroon ("CAPECE"), financed by the
            International Development Association (IDA). The Request for
            Inspection was submitted by the Center for Environment and
            Development (CED), a local nongovernmental organization
            (NGO) based in Yaounde, representing several residents who
            live along the pipeline route, as well as several workers or
            sub-contractors of Cameroon Oil Transportation Company S.A.
            (COTCO), who are all resident in the Republic of Cameroon
            ("Requestors"). The Executive Directors and the
            President of IBRD and IDA ("the Bank") were
            notified by the Panel of receipt of the Request. Management
            responded to the claims in the Request on October 29,2002.
            Management replied to twenty-six specific claims, which
            concerned the Bank's policies on Environmental
            Assessment, Natural Habitats, Indigenous Peoples,
            Involuntary Resettlement, Poverty Reduction and Supervision
            as well as matters related to labor relations and HN/AIDS.
            Management's response provided detailed discussion of
            cumulative impacts, institutional development, protected
            areas, the Bakola/Bagyeli people, compensation payments and
            processes, the Bank's intensified supervision of the
            Pipeline Project and labor relations. In its Report to the
            Board, the Panel found the Request eligible and recommended
            that the Executive Directors authorize an investigation. The
            investigation was authorized by the Executive Directors on
            December 16,2002. On May 2,2003, the Panel issued its Report
            (no. 25734) outlining the findings of the investigation.
            This report, responds to the findings of the Panel. It is
            organized in five sections. After the Introduction, Section
            2 provides an overview of the status of the projects.
            Section 3 summarizes the findings of the Panel. Section 4
            presents Management's Action Plan in response to the
            Panel's findings, and Section 5 contains the
            conclusion. The Panel's findings, along with
            Management's responses, are presented in detail in
            Annex 1 and relevant Terms of Reference (TORS) are included
            in Annex 2.

            in Response to the Inspection Panel Report

abstracts.cdata!:
On September 30,2002 the Inspection
            Panel registered a Request for Inspection, (hereafter
            referred to as "the Request"), concerning the
            Petroleum Development and Pipeline Project in Cameroon (the
            "Pipeline Project"), financed by the International
            Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), and the
            Petroleum Environment Capacity Enhancement (CAPECE) Project
            in Cameroon ("CAPECE"), financed by the
            International Development Association (IDA). The Request for
            Inspection was submitted by the Center for Environment and
            Development (CED), a local nongovernmental organization
            (NGO) based in Yaounde, representing several residents who
            live along the pipeline route, as well as several workers or
            sub-contractors of Cameroon Oil Transportation Company S.A.
            (COTCO), who are all resident in the Republic of Cameroon
            ("Requestors"). The Executive Directors and the
            President of IBRD and IDA ("the Bank") were
            notified by the Panel of receipt of the Request. Management
            responded to the claims in the Request on October 29,2002.
            Management replied to twenty-six specific claims, which
            concerned the Bank's policies on Environmental
            Assessment, Natural Habitats, Indigenous Peoples,
            Involuntary Resettlement, Poverty Reduction and Supervision
            as well as matters related to labor relations and HN/AIDS.
            Management's response provided detailed discussion of
            cumulative impacts, institutional development, protected
            areas, the Bakola/Bagyeli people, compensation payments and
            processes, the Bank's intensified supervision of the
            Pipeline Project and labor relations. In its Report to the
            Board, the Panel found the Request eligible and recommended
            that the Executive Directors authorize an investigation. The
            investigation was authorized by the Executive Directors on
            December 16,2002. On May 2,2003, the Panel issued its Report
            (no. 25734) outlining the findings of the investigation.
            This report, responds to the findings of the Panel. It is
            organized in five sections. After the Introduction, Section
            2 provides an overview of the status of the projects.
            Section 3 summarizes the findings of the Panel. Section 4
            presents Management's Action Plan in response to the
            Panel's findings, and Section 5 contains the
            conclusion. The Panel's findings, along with
            Management's responses, are presented in detail in
            Annex 1 and relevant Terms of Reference (TORS) are included
            in Annex 2.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Request for Inspection of the
            Cameroon Petroleum Development and Pipeline Project outlines
            problems caused to the indigenous communities that border
            the pipeline area, as detailed by the Center for the
            Environment and Development (CED).  The request details
            several claims to the destruction of natural resources as a
            result of the pipeline construction, including the
            dissemination of medicinal plants and the scarcity of game.
            The request also claims that the indigenous communities were
            not informed properly during the pipeline's planning
            stages and there has been a lack of respect and compensation
            for workers in the area while construction is taking place.
